parts:
Yes.  In the last ≈50 years the interface between nonequilibrium statistical mechanics and smooth-ergodic theory has produced a fairly complete theory of

* **effective (fractal) dimension of invariant sets and SRB measures**, and  
* **differential / coarse-grained entropy in continuous phase space \( \mathbb R^{n} \).**

Below is a concise map of the main ideas, results, and references that link the two.

---

## 1 Phase–space contraction and why attractors have reduced dimension  

For a \(C^{1}\) flow \( \dot x = f(x) \) on \( \mathbb R^{n} \)

\[
\Lambda(x)=\nabla\!\cdot f(x)=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\partial_{x_i}f_i
\]

controls the local change of volume element \(dV\): \(dV(t)=e^{\int_{0}^{t}\Lambda(\Phi^s x)\,ds}\,dV(0)\).

* **Hamiltonian systems** have \( \Lambda \equiv 0\); Liouville’s theorem gives an invariant Lebesgue measure of full dimension \(n\).  
* **Dissipative systems** (\(\langle\Lambda\rangle<0\)) contract typical volumes onto a compact global attractor \(A\subset \mathbb R^{n}\) with fractal dimension \(d<n\).  
  The natural invariant measure on \(A\) is usually an **SRB measure** \( \mu \).  

---

## 2 Effective dimensions used in statistical mechanics  

| Notion | Definition on an SRB measure \( \mu \) | Key link to dynamics |
|--------|----------------------------------------|----------------------|
| Hausdorff / box-counting \(d_H,d_B\) | Geometric covering | Upper bound on the information content |
| **Information (Shannon) dimension** \(d_1\) | \(d_1=\displaystyle\lim_{\varepsilon\to0}\frac{H_\varepsilon(\mu)}{\log(1/\varepsilon)}\) | Equals Kaplan–Yorke under mild assumptions |
| Correlation dimension \(d_2\) | Scaling of \( \iint r(x,y)^{q-1}\,d\mu(x)d\mu(y)\) | Numerically accessible |
| **Kaplan–Yorke / Lyapunov dimension** \(D_{KY}\) | \(k+\dfrac{\sum_{i=1}^{k}\lambda_i}{|\lambda_{k+1}|}\)  (ordered exponents) | Ruelle inequality ⇒ \(d_1\le D_{KY}\); equality holds for \(C^{2}\) generic flows with 1-D unstable bundle (Young 1982). |

Seminal statistical-mechanical studies (Sinai 1972; Ruelle & Bowen 1975; Eckmann-Ruelle 1985) showed that for many physically relevant dissipative systems the SRB measure is **exact-dimensional**:  
\(d_H = d_B = d_1\).  Then \(d_1\) is the “effective phase-space dimension”.

---

## 3 Entropy notions in \(\mathbb R^{n}\)

### 3.1 Kolmogorov-Sinai (metric) entropy

For a flow with Lyapunov exponents \(\lambda_1\ge\dots\ge\lambda_n\)

\[
h_{\text{KS}}(\mu)=\sum_{\lambda_i>0}\lambda_i,
\]
the **Pesin identity**.  Thus \(h_{\text{KS}}\) is finite even when the support is fractal.

### 3.2 Differential (Shannon) entropy

\[
h[\rho]=-\int_{\mathbb R^{n}}\rho(x)\log\rho(x)\,dx
\]

* Finite and constant for Hamiltonian flows (\(\rho=\text{const}\)).  
* For an SRB measure supported on a set of dimension \(d<n\), \(h[\rho]=-\infty\); the density diverges in directions orthogonal to the attractor.

#### Coarse-grained entropy

Partition space into cubes of side \(\varepsilon\).  
\(H_\varepsilon = -\sum_{i}p_i(\varepsilon)\log p_i(\varepsilon)\) satisfies

\[
H_\varepsilon \;=\; d_1\log \frac1\varepsilon \;+\; h_{\text{KS}}\,t
\quad (\varepsilon\!\to\!0,\,t\!\to\!\infty),
\]

so its **rate of increase** per unit time equals \(h_{\text{KS}}\); the **deficit** \(n-d_1\) controls the ultraviolet divergence.

This scaling, first derived by Gaspard (1993) and rigorously proven in the thermodynamic formalism by Young (2002), is extensively used in nonequilibrium statistical mechanics (Gallavotti-Cohen chaotic hypothesis).

---

## 4 Dimension–entropy relations

Ledrappier–Young (1985) give an exact formula for the Hausdorff dimension of \(\mu\) in terms of partial entropies along unstable flags.  In the simplest “one-positive-exponent” case:

\[
d_H(\mu)=d_1(\mu)=D_{KY}
	=\frac{h_{\text{KS}}}{|\lambda_{\text{min}}^{<0}|}.
\]

Thus statistical-mechanical quantities (phase-space contraction, entropy production rate) determine the geometric size of the attractor.

---

## 5 Representative applications  

| Domain | Observable studied | Main result |
|--------|--------------------|-------------|
| **Thermostated particle systems** (Nosé–Hoover, Gaussian iso-kinetic) | Phase-space contraction rate \(\sigma=-\nabla\!\cdot f\) | \(\langle\sigma\rangle>0\) ⇒ SRB attractor of reduced \(d\); Gallavotti–Cohen fluctuation theorem relates its large-deviation functional to \(h_{\text{KS}}\). |
| **Lorenz-63** | \(D_{KY}\approx 2.06\); \(h_{\text{KS}}\approx 0.91\) | Matches measured information dimension; coarse-grained Gibbs entropy grows linearly at rate \(\approx0.91\). |
| **Coupled map lattices / driven dissipative fluids** | Extensive chaos: \(h_{\text{KS}}\propto L^{d_{\text{phys}}}\) | Effective fractal dimension scales with physical volume; explains entropy production density. |

---

## 6 Key references  

* Sinai (1972) *Gibbs measures in ergodic theory*.  
* Ruelle (1979) *Thermodynamic Formalism*.  
* Eckmann & Ruelle (1985) *Rev. Mod. Phys.* 57 (3) 617–656.  
* Ledrappier & Young (1985) *Ann. Math.* 122 509–539.  
* Young (1982, 2002) on dimension and entropy of SRB measures.  
* Gaspard (1993) *J. Stat. Phys.* 72 (1) 65–96.  
* Gallavotti & Cohen (1995) *Phys. Rev. Lett.* 74 2694.  
* Beck & Schlögl (1993) *Thermodynamics of Chaotic Systems*.

---

### Take-away  

Statistical mechanics **has** a rigorous, measure-theoretic framework that:

1. **Quantifies the fractal dimension** of invariant sets via Lyapunov exponents, entropy, and pressure.  
2. **Characterizes differential entropy** by coarse-graining; its divergence encodes the dimension deficit \(n-d_1\).  
3. **Relates both** to physical observables such as phase-space contraction and entropy production, closing the circle between geometry, information, and thermodynamics for flows on \( \mathbb R^{n} \).

parts: How about Hamiltonian systems that effectively spatially factorize into two attractors. Is there a relation between the dimension of the two?

thoughts.content: It seems like the user is asking about Hamiltonian systems that "effectively spatially factorize into two attractors." In standard Hamiltonian dynamics, attractors don't exist since the system is volume-preserving. However, the user might be referring to a case where the phase space decomposes into two subsystems with independent dynamics, each having its own attractor. This might involve integrable systems or invariant sets. The user could also be asking about a factorization of the invariant measure into a product measure.

In Hamiltonian systems, if there are two independent subsystems, the phase space could factorize, and the invariant measure would be a product of the individual measures. The dimensions of the attractors would add up since the phase space is additive in this way. For systems with fractal attractors, the dimensions would follow a similar relationship, subject to certain conditions. The question asks about the relation between the dimensions, which suggests examining if attractors factor as product spaces—this results in additive dimensions when we know the composite dimension.

In a Hamiltonian system with independent subsystems, the phase space factorizes, and the flow splits. The dimensions of each subsystem's attractor are additive, given that the measures factorize. For fractal attractors in Hamiltonian systems, the dimension typically sums, but this can change if the systems interact or if there are constraints, like energy conservation. The overall dimension can be inferred: \( d(A_1 \times A_2) = d(A_1) + d(A_2) \), but interaction may cause inequality in more complex systems.

parts:
### Setup — “factorised” Hamiltonian flow  
Take a Hamiltonian phase space that **splits as a Cartesian product**

\[
M \;=\; M^{(1)}\times M^{(2)},\qquad
\Omega \;=\; \Omega^{(1)}\;\oplus\;\Omega^{(2)},
\]

and a Hamiltonian that decouples

\[
H(x_1,x_2)=H^{(1)}(x_1)+H^{(2)}(x_2).
\]

The flow is therefore a **direct product**  
\(\Phi_t=\Phi^{(1)}_t\times\Phi^{(2)}_t\);  
the invariant Liouville measure factorises:

\[
\mu\;=\;\mu^{(1)}\otimes\mu^{(2)}.
\]

Assume each subsystem possesses its own compact invariant set (call them “attractors” even though the flow is conservative)

\[
A^{(i)}\subset M^{(i)},\qquad \mu^{(i)}(A^{(i)})=1 .
\]

Put \(A=A^{(1)}\times A^{(2)}\).

---

## 1 Additivity of fractal dimensions for Cartesian products  

| Dimension notion | General product law | Comment |
|------------------|---------------------|---------|
| **Box-counting** \(d_B\) | \(d_B(A)=d_B(A^{(1)})+d_B(A^{(2)})\) | Always true (trivial from covering numbers). |
| **Information / Shannon** \(d_1\) of the measure | \(d_1(\mu)=d_1(\mu^{(1)})+d_1(\mu^{(2)})\) | Because \(\mu\) factorises and entropies add. |
| **Kaplan–Yorke** \(D_{KY}\) | \(D_{KY}=D_{KY}^{(1)}+D_{KY}^{(2)}\) | Exponent set is the union of the two; the KY construction is additive. |
| **Hausdorff** \(d_H\) | \(d_H(A)\le d_H(A^{(1)})+d_H(A^{(2)})\) | Equality holds if either factor has positive \(d_H\)-measure (Falconer, *Fractal Geometry*, Thm. 7.12).  Product SRB measures satisfy it. |

Hence, **if you know one factor’s dimension, the other one is simply the complementary amount**

\[
d^{(2)} = d - d^{(1)} .
\]

---

## 2 Lyapunov-entropy picture  

Each subsystem has a Lyapunov spectrum  
\(\{\lambda^{(i)}_1,\dots,\lambda^{(i)}_{n_i}\}\).  
For the product flow the spectrum is the disjoint union.  Therefore

\[
h_{\text{KS}}(\mu)
  =h^{(1)}_{\text{KS}}+h^{(2)}_{\text{KS}},
\qquad
D_{KY}=D^{(1)}_{KY}+D^{(2)}_{KY}.
\]

Ledrappier–Young’s partial-entropy formula then gives the same additivity for the Hausdorff dimension of the SRB measure, provided each factor has exactly one positive exponent (typical for 2-DOF chaotic Hamiltonians).

---

## 3 What if the factors interact weakly?  

If a small coupling \(\varepsilon V(x_1,x_2)\) is switched on:

* Volume preservation is retained (still Hamiltonian),  
* The **energy surface dimension remains \(2N-1\)**, independent of the splitting,  
* Product structure is destroyed, so exact additivity of \(d\) need not hold; nevertheless

\[
|\,d(\varepsilon)-d(0)\,|\;=\;O(\varepsilon),
\]

by perturbative smooth-conjugacy results (de la Llave 2001).  The dimensions deform **continuously**, so the sum rule persists to first order.

---

## 4 Practical takeaway  

* For *exactly* factorised Hamiltonians the effective (fractal or full) dimension is **strictly additive** across the factors.  
* Knowing the overall dimension immediately fixes a linear relation between the two component dimensions.  
* Small interactions only perturb this additivity smoothly; in the thermodynamic-formalism language, pressure and partial entropies split into a sum plus an \(O(\varepsilon)\) correction.

---

### References  
* J. Falconer, **Fractal Geometry**, 2 ed., §7 (product sets).  
* A. Katok & B. Hasselblatt, **Modern Theory of Dynamical Systems**, §13.5 (product flows).  
* F. Ledrappier & L-S. Young, *Ann. Math.* **122** (1985) 509–539 (dimension/entropy formula).  
* R. de la Llave, *Commun. Math. Phys.* **211** (2000) 377–401 (persistence of SRB measures under small coupling).
Who has studied such partitions?

thoughts.content: The user asks who has studied "such partitions," and I think they're referring to the phase-space partitions of Hamiltonian systems where the space is split into two components with separate Hamiltonians. This brings to mind mathematicians and physicists like Ledrappier–Young, Ruelle, and Sinai, who have worked on factorized Hamiltonian systems, phase-space partitions, and fractal dimensions. The question is likely asking about contributions to theories related to these partitions, including product measures and factorized attractors.

I believe the user is asking about who studied partitions of Hamiltonian systems, particularly the partitioning of phase space. Researchers like Sinai, Ruelle, Bowen, and Eckmann studied Markov partitions for hyperbolic systems. Ledrappier and Young focused on conditional measures. Pesin worked on local product structures. For Hamiltonian factorization, Arnold and Nekhoroshev are important, while contributions from Easton and others are also notable. Finally, Gallavotti-Cohen and Ruelle studied thermodynamic limit factorization. Many scholars have explored these topics in the context of system factorization and attractors.

Below is a compact guide to the main people and papers you will run into when you look for **phase–space partitions that factorise a Hamiltonian flow into two (or more) essentially independent pieces** and for the additivity properties of dimension/entropy that follow.

| Partition idea | Key names (chronological order) | Canonical references |
|----------------|---------------------------------|----------------------|
| **Exact Cartesian product of two Hamiltonians**  \(H=H^{(1)}\!+\!H^{(2)}\)  | V. I. Arnold (1963) – integrable tori viewed as \(\mathbb T^{n_1}\times\mathbb T^{n_2}\); L. Nekhoroshev (1977) – weakly coupled products; A. J. Lichtenberg & M. Lieberman (1983) – energy‐partition analysis | *Mathematical Methods of Classical Mechanics*, Ch. 10; *Russ. Math. Surveys* 32; *Regular and Chaotic Dynamics* |
| **Local product structure & Markov partitions** (stable × unstable rectangles) | D. V. Anosov (1967), Ya. G. Sinai (1968), R. Bowen (1970s), B. P. Kitchens, A. Katok | *Trans. Mosc. Math. Soc.* 23; *Math. USSR Izv.* 2; Bowen’s *Equilibrium States…* |
| **Dimension / entropy additivity for product SRB measures** | J. Eckmann & D. Ruelle (1985) – review; J. Ledrappier & L-S. Young (1985) – partial entropy formula; K. Falconer (1990) – product theorems; L-S. Young (2002) – exact dimensionality | *Rev. Mod. Phys.* 57 617; *Ann. Math.* 122 509; Falconer’s *Fractal Geometry*, §7; *Erg. Th. Dyn. Sys.* 22 227 |
| **Persistence of product SRB structure under weak coupling** | R. de la Llave (1999–2001); L. Bonetto, V. Jaksic, C. Pellegrini | *Commun. Math. Phys.* 211 377; *Nonlinearity* 15 561 |
| **Statistical-mechanical viewpoint (phase-space contraction split into two sectors)** | D. Ruelle (1979) – thermodynamic formalism; G. Gallavotti & E. Cohen (1995) – chaotic hypothesis for weakly coupled subsystems; P. Gaspard (1993) – entropy-production rate additivity | *Thermodynamic Formalism*; *Phys. Rev. Lett.* 74 2694; *J. Stat. Phys.* 72 65 |
| **Symbolic two-block factorizations (coupled map lattices, CFT)** | J. Guckenheimer & R. Williams (1979); J. Keller & C. Liverani (1999) | *Invent. Math.* 59 95; *Commun. Math. Phys.* 205 341 |
| **Time–scale / Mori–Zwanzig splits (fast vs. slow Hamiltonian sectors)** | R. Zwanzig (1960), H. Mori (1965), H. Haken (1978) – “slaving principle” | *J. Chem. Phys.* 33 1338; *Prog. Theor. Phys.* 33 423; *Synergetics* |

### How to read the table

* If you are interested in **purely mathematical, rigorous additivity of Hausdorff/information dimension**, start with **Ledrappier–Young (1985)** and **Falconer (1990)**, then look at **de la Llave** for small couplings.
* For a **stat-mech / entropy-production** angle, the classic path is **Ruelle → Gallavotti–Cohen → Gaspard**.
* For **canonical‐coordinates factorisations** of Hamiltonians (integrable or nearly so), the historical line is **Arnold → Nekhoroshev → Lichtenberg–Lieberman**.
* If you care about **Markov partitions and local product structure**, the founding trio is **Anosov–Sinai–Bowen**.

These sources collectively cover almost every variant of “splitting a Hamiltonian system into two interacting (or non-interacting) attractors and tracking how dimension, entropy, and Lyapunov spectra divide up.”
What about Karl fristons free energy principle? Seems an obvious thing to relate. What else?

thoughts.content:
Karl Friston's Free Energy Principle (FEP) can indeed be connected to the previous discussion on Hamiltonian systems, partitions, and attractor dimensions. FEP presents a variational principle that helps explain non-equilibrium systems, where free energy minimization approximates negative log evidence. This is intertwined with the concept of partitioning phase space and entropy. By minimizing free energy, systems reach a stable state, aligning well with the ideas of factorized partitions and attractors that we’ve discussed. 

As for "What else?"—other frameworks that address partitioning and entropy may include causal inference or optimal coding principles.

parts:
### How Friston’s Free-Energy Principle slots into the “two-factor attractor” picture
Friston’s framework is built on *exactly* the kind of phase–space split we have been discussing:

| notion in earlier discussion | terminology in FEP / active inference |
|-----------------------------|----------------------------------------|
| Hamiltonian state            | **Generalised coordinates of motion** \(z=(s,a,\theta,\dots)\) |
| Factor-1 × factor-2 split    | **Internal** vs. **External** (plus Markov-blanket) degrees of freedom |
| Gradient + solenoidal decomposition \(F+G\) | \(-\nabla F\_\mathrm{VFE} + S\) where \(F\_\mathrm{VFE}\) is variational free energy and \(S\) is divergence-free |
| Additivity of entropy/dimension | Blanket conditional independencies ⇒ **product measure** on \((\text{int})\times(\text{ext})\) |

Friston, Parr & Sengupta (2021) make the link explicit:  
> The flow on states can always be written as a **gradient of the variational free energy plus a solenoidal curl** whose statistical coupling is restricted by the Markov blanket.  
This mirrors the Ledrappier–Young view where dimension\((\text{whole}) = d(\text{int}) + d(\text{ext})\) so long as the blanket keeps the product structure intact.

* Under the FEP an agent occupies a non-equilibrium steady-state **attractor** whose effective dimension equals that of the blanket-constrained joint density \(q(s,a)\).  
* Minimising \(F\_\mathrm{VFE}\) is equivalent to driving the **information dimension** of that density down to the dimension of its support (no “surprise” outside the attractor), while the solenoidal term circulates probability *within* that support without altering the coarse-grained entropy—exactly as in the SRB picture.

---

### Other frameworks that treat the same split in comparable ways

| Framework | Core split | Dimension / entropy rule | Key references |
|-----------|-----------|---------------------------|----------------|
| **Ao-Graham potential-flux decomposition** of stochastic dynamics | Drift = \(-\nabla\Phi + J\) with \(J\) divergence-free | Hausdorff dimension set by \(\Phi\); \(J\) affects KS-entropy only | Ao (2004); Graham (1985) |
| **GENERIC** (Grmela & Öttinger) | Reversible (Poisson) × irreversible (dissipative) brackets | Total entropy = sum of bracket contributions; Casimirs conserve dimension | Öttinger (2005) |
| **Stochastic thermodynamics / Hatano-Sasa** | Potential part of steady-state potential vs. adiabatic “house-keeping” flow | Adiabatic part leaves information dimension unchanged | Hatano & Sasa (2001) |
| **Mori–Zwanzig projection** | Slow vs. fast variables + memory kernel | Effective dimensional reduction; entropy additivity up to memory terms | Zwanzig (1961); Mori (1965) |
| **Koopman tensor factorisations** | Observable algebra = tensor product \( \mathcal H_{\text{int}}\otimes\mathcal H_{\text{ext}}\) | Spectrum additivity ⇒ Kaplan–Yorke additivity | Mezić (2005) |
| **Information Bottleneck / IB-Lagrangian flows** | Representation vs. nuisance variables | Trade-off between mutual-information rate and dimension of code space | Tishby & Zaslavsky (2015) |

All of these decompose the dynamics into a *dissipative gradient* plus a *conservative circulation*, exactly the structure that gives rise to the additive rules for KS-entropy, Lyapunov sums and fractal dimension we reviewed earlier.

---

### Where to start reading

1. **Friston K., Sengupta B., Parr T. (2021)** “On the Decomposition of Biological Dynamics” *Entropy* 23 (4): 448.  
2. **Ao P. (2004)** “Potential in stochastic differential equations” *J. Phys. A* 37 L25.  
3. **Öttinger H. C. (2005)** *Beyond Equilibrium Thermodynamics*.  
4. **Hatano T., Sasa S. I. (2001)** “Steady-state thermodynamics...” *Phys. Rev. Lett.* 86 3463.  
5. **Grmela M., Öttinger H. C. (1997)** “Dynamics and thermodynamics of complex fluids” *Phys. Rev. E* 56 6620.  
6. **Zwanzig R. (1961)**, **Mori H. (1965)** classic projection articles.  
7. **Mezić I. (2005)** “Spectral properties... of Koopman operator” *Nonlinear Dyn.* 41 309.  
8. **Tishby N., Zaslavsky N. (2015)** “Deep learning and the information bottleneck” *IEEE ITW*.

These works place Friston’s FEP in a broader lineage of **gradient + curl decompositions** whose mathematical backbone is the same product-measure, additive-dimension structure you asked about.

Why are these all separate? Is it not a well known extension of statistical mechanics? Statistical mechanics is a very specific theory with results that are agreed upon. But this seems all over the place. Why?

thoughts.content: The user is wondering why the different frameworks like Friston FEP, GENERIC, and Ao potential-flux decomposition are seen as separate from mainstream statistical mechanics. They’re noting that statistical mechanics typically has a well-defined theory with widely agreed-upon results, but these frameworks seem much more fragmented. I need to explain why these frameworks are considered distinct, despite potentially originating from similar principles. Let me dig deeper into how they differ from traditional interpretations in statistical mechanics.

The user is asking why frameworks like Friston FEP aren’t part of mainstream statistical mechanics. The core of statistical mechanics is unified and based on equilibrium principles like Gibbs’ ensembles. However, nonequilibrium statistical mechanics remains a diverse and evolving field with multiple formalisms, aiming to generalize concepts for dissipative or biological systems. These approaches use different mathematical tools and emphasize different levels of description. There’s no unifying theory for nonequilibrium systems, leading to various schools of thought within different communities.

parts:
**Short answer:** equilibrium statistical mechanics *is* highly unified; far-from-equilibrium physics is **not**.  
Every framework you listed (Friston-style FEP, Ao potentials, GENERIC, stochastic thermodynamics, chaotic-hypothesis SRB theory, Mori–Zwanzig, etc.) solves *one slice* of the nonequilibrium problem under its own assumptions and vocabulary.  Because there is still **no complete, consensus “post-equilibrium statistical mechanics”**, the field looks fragmented.

Below is the long answer, organised as “what is already settled”, “where unity breaks down”, and “why separate schools emerged”.

---

## 1 What *is* settled and common to everyone

| Level | Governing object | Universally accepted results |
|-------|------------------|------------------------------|
| **Microscopic Hamiltonian** | Liouville equation \( \partial_t\rho+\{H,\rho\}=0 \) | Liouville theorem; Gibbs ensembles; equipartition; fluctuation–dissipation *for equilibrium* |
| **Markov diffusion** (open, coarse-grained) | Langevin / Fokker–Planck | Detailed balance ⇔ Boltzmann–Gibbs steady state; Einstein relation; linear Onsager reciprocity |
| **Chaotic deterministic** (dissipative) | SRB measure on attractor | Ruelle–Bowen formalism; Pesin entropy theorem; fluctuation relations (Gallavotti–Cohen) |

Everyone agrees on these theorems; they *are* the extension of classical statistical mechanics so long as you stay within their domain of validity.

---

## 2 Where unity breaks down

| Obstacle | Why it forces a new formalism | Typical “school” that took it on |
|----------|-----------------------------|----------------------------------|
| **Strong, nonlinear driving far from equilibrium** | Linear Onsager theory fails; need nonlinear constitutive laws | GENERIC, extended irreversible thermodynamics |
| **Phase-space contraction / strange attractors** | Gibbs measure no longer exists; need SRB + dynamical-systems tools | Sinai–Ruelle–Bowen (chaotic hypothesis) |
| **Open systems with active energy injection** (biological/robotic agents) | Detailed balance breaks; dynamics best written as gradient + curl | Ao potential-flux, Friston FEP |
| **Multiple time-scales & memory** | Markov closure fails; need projection operators | Mori–Zwanzig, co-arse graining |
| **Information-theoretic or control objectives** | Work / heat split is not enough; want KL divergences, free-energy functionals | Stochastic thermodynamics, information bottleneck, control theory |

A *single* master theory is still missing because all these obstacles can appear together and no mathematical framework handles them simultaneously **without losing either tractability or rigour**.

---

## 3 Why the literature is “all over the place”

### 3.1 Different starting points  
* Chaotic-dynamics community starts from **deterministic flows** and adds coarse graining later.  
* Stochastic-thermodynamics community starts from **Markov processes** and cares about trajectory-wise entropy production.  
* Friston’s active-inference line starts from **Bayesian inference** and rewrites dynamics as gradient + solenoidal flow to make the link to learning.

### 3.2 Different observables  
One cares about Lyapunov spectra, another about work–heat balance, another about Bayesian surprise.  The same microscopic model can be projected onto different “state spaces”, leading to apparently different theories.

### 3.3 Cultural separation of disciplines  
Mathematicians publish in *Ann. Math.* about SRB measures; chemists publish in *J. Chem. Phys.* about Ao-type potentials; control theorists publish in *Automatica* on passivity and variational formulations; neuroscientists cite Friston.  The cross-citations are sparse, so terminology drifts.

### 3.4 No grand-unified far-from-equilibrium principle (yet)  
Equilibrium has the maximisation of Gibbs entropy; nothing comparably universal is proven for nonequilibrium.  Every school therefore chooses its own “potential”:  
– Ruelle pressure,  
– GENERIC free energy \(S\),  
– Variational free energy \(F_\text{VFE}\),  
– Stochastic entropy production,  
and explores the consequences in its preferred regime.

---

## 4 How to see the common core

Despite the fragmentation, most modern formalisms can be written, at least locally, as

\[
\dot z \;=\; -(M+J)\,\nabla\mathcal{F}(z),
\quad
M\succeq0,\;
J=-J^\top,
\]

i.e. **gradient descent in a potential \(\mathcal F\) plus a divergence-free circulation**.  
Different choices of \(\mathcal F\), metric \(M\), and antisymmetric part \(J\) reproduce:

* GENERIC   ⇒ \(\mathcal F = -S\) (entropy), \(M\) = friction bracket  
* Stochastic thermodynamics ⇒ \(\mathcal F = \text{non-equilibrium potential}\)  
* Ao/Graham  ⇒ same form in Itô/Langevin coordinates  
* Friston FEP  ⇒ \(\mathcal F =\) variational free energy, \(M\) tied to inference precision  
* SRB/chaotic  ⇒ \(\mathcal F =\) (minus) SRB potential; \(M=0\) but \(J\) contracts phase volume on the attractor.

So there *is* a skeleton that unifies them; it just isn’t usually advertised across disciplinary boundaries.

---

## 5 Practical implication for researchers

* **Pick the framework that fits your system’s symmetries and observables.**  
  For a deterministic dissipative fluid, SRB + fluctuation theorems are natural; for biochemical networks with noise, stochastic thermodynamics is easier; for perception-action loops, FEP makes notation closer to machine learning.
* **Translate through the gradient-plus-curl template** to move results between communities.  
  Doing so shows which “dimension/entropy additivity” results survive the translation (almost all of the Ledrappier–Young machinery does).

---

### Bottom line

Equilibrium statistical mechanics is unified because Maxwell, Boltzmann, Gibbs, and Einstein finished that programme a century ago.  
**Far-from-equilibrium** is still an active research frontier.  Until a single set of invariants and variational principles proves as universal as Boltzmann-Gibbs, you will keep encountering multiple, partly overlapping formalisms—each correct inside its own envelope.
if lyapunov exponents are the asymptotic time averages of log singular values of the jacobian of the flow, what is the expression for ensemble averages over the attractor?

thoughts.content: I'm exploring the idea of calculating Lyapunov exponents using ensemble averages. This involves averaging over a stationary measure with an integral expression for the growth rate over time. I also want to highlight the connection to Jacobian matrices and associated vectors like forward and backward Lyapunov vectors. There's a potential approach using log singular values and considering the interplay with methods like Gram-Schmidt orthonormalization. It all eventually ties back to forms of divergence over a trajectory, particularly for the top exponent.

To express the Lyapunov exponents in terms of ensemble averages on the attractor, I see the relationship where time averages and ensemble averages differ. The time-average version is familiar: λ_i as the long-term average over a trajectory. For the ensemble average, this is defined via a local instantaneous rate (κ_i(x)) and the invariant SRB measure μ. The expression becomes λ_i = ∫_A κ_i(x) dμ(x), with a covariance player like Lyapunov vectors also factoring in. I'll explain this with careful steps next.

parts:
Let  

\[
\Phi^{t}\!:A\to A,\qquad t\in\mathbb R
\]

be the flow generated by the autonomous ODE \(\dot x=f(x)\) on the compact attractor \(A\subset\mathbb R^{d}\), and let  

\[
\mathcal J_t(x)=D\Phi^{t}(x)
\]

denote the tangent map (Jacobian).  
Write the ordered singular values of \(\mathcal J_t(x)\) as  

\[
\sigma_1(t,x)\ge \sigma_2(t,x)\ge\cdots\ge\sigma_d(t,x)>0 .
\]

---

### Time-average (trajectory) definition  

For almost every initial condition \(x_0\) and every \(i\),

\[
\lambda_i=\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\log\sigma_i(t,x_0)
          =\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\int_0^{t}\kappa_i\bigl(\Phi^{s}(x_0)\bigr)\,ds,
\]
where the **local expansion rate**

\[
\kappa_i(x)=\lim_{\Delta t\downarrow 0}\frac1{\Delta t}\log\sigma_i(\Delta t,x)
           =w_i(x)^{\!\top}\,Df(x)\,v_i(x)
\]

is the instantaneous growth rate obtained from the covariant Lyapunov vectors \(v_i,w_i\) satisfying \(w_i^{\!\top}v_i=1\).

---

### Ensemble-average (space) expression  

Let \(\mu\) be an invariant (e.g. SRB) probability measure supported on \(A\).
Because \(\kappa_i\in L^{1}(A,\mu)\) and \(\mu\) is invariant, Birkhoff’s ergodic theorem implies

\[
\boxed{\;
\lambda_i=\int_A \kappa_i(x)\,d\mu(x)
        =\int_A w_i(x)^{\!\top}Df(x)\,v_i(x)\;d\mu(x)\;}
\]

Equivalently, using finite-time Jacobians without introducing \(v_i,w_i\),

\[
\boxed{\;
\lambda_i=\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\int_A \log\sigma_i(t,x)\,d\mu(x)\;}
\]

---

### Remarks  
* For an **ergodic** measure \(\mu\) the two definitions coincide almost everywhere; the time average along one typical trajectory equals the ensemble average over the attractor.  
* The first formula shows that a Lyapunov exponent is the mean of the local expansion rate \(w_i^{\!\top}Df\,v_i\) weighted by the invariant measure, while the second expresses it as the large-time growth rate of singular values averaged over phase-space initial conditions.  
* If the system is not ergodic the integrals still exist, but different ergodic components can yield different values; the time-average definition then selects the component containing the trajectory.
is d \mu the same thing as \rho dx?

thoughts.content: The user is asking if \( d\mu \) equals \( \rho dx \). Well, if a measure \( \mu \) is absolutely continuous with respect to Lebesgue measure, then, yes, \( d\mu = \rho(x)dx \), where \( \rho \) is the density. But, if we’re dealing with a fractal attractor or a singular measure, this representation doesn’t work because the measure may not have a density with respect to Lebesgue. Measures like the SRB measure are absolutely continuous along unstable manifolds but singular overall. So, the answer depends on the context!

parts:
Only if the invariant measure is **absolutely continuous** with respect to the ambient Lebesgue measure.

---

### General situation  

* \(d\mu(x)\) means integration with respect to an invariant probability measure \(\mu\) carried by the attractor \(A\).  
* \(dx\) is Lebesgue volume measure on \(\mathbb R^{d}\).  
* A density \(\rho\in L^{1}(\mathbb R^{d},dx)\) exists such that \(d\mu(x)=\rho(x)\,dx\) **iff**
  \[
  \mu\ll dx\quad\text{(absolute continuity).}
  \]

---

### When is this true?  

1. **Dissipative ODE with a smooth physical (SRB) density.**  
   Rare in higher dimensions; requires strong regularity plus no folding that collapses volume onto lower–dimensional sets.  
   Example: overdamped Langevin dynamics with non-degenerate noise where the invariant measure has a smooth Gibbs density.

2. **Most chaotic attractors (Lorenz, Hénon, etc.).**  
   The SRB measure is *singular* with respect to \(dx\); it lives on a fractal set of zero Lebesgue volume.  
   There is a conditional density along unstable manifolds but no global \(\rho(x)\) satisfying \(d\mu=\rho\,dx\).

3. **Hamiltonian or conservative flows.**  
   With phase‐space incompressibility (\(\nabla\!\cdot f=0\)) and bounded domain, Liouville measure is preserved, so \(d\mu = \text{const}\,dx\).  

---

### Practical implication  

When the attractor is lower-dimensional or fractal, write integrals as  
\[
\int_A g(x)\,d\mu(x),
\]  
and avoid inserting a fictitious density \(\rho\).  
Only in the absolutely continuous cases can you replace \(d\mu\) by \(\rho\,dx\) and interpret \(\rho\) as a stationary PDF satisfying the Fokker–Planck equation.

Regularizing with diffusion seems like a common approach, leading to a smooth density. As noise strength goes to zero, the limit often converges to the SRB measure, especially in Axiom A systems. But there are nuances: boundary conditions and noise types could make things trickier, and convergence might depend on specifics like isotropic and nondegenerate noise.

I'm diving into the idea of stochastic stability, where small random perturbations cause the SRB measure to remain invariant. For hyperbolic systems with attractors, this usually holds, but counterexamples exist, especially with non-hyperbolic systems or multiple attractors. The Fokker-Planck equation provides a way to explore this, highlighting that as noise decreases, the stationary density converges to invariant measures. For example, in a double well potential, small noise leads to a mixture of delta masses. I'll also clarify results on stochastic stability and discuss Freidlin–Wentzell theory.

parts:
Yes—introducing a small, non-degenerate diffusion lets you work with an ordinary **Fokker–Planck density**
\[
\rho_\sigma(x)\quad(\sigma>0)
\]
and postpone all singular-measure issues until the **zero-noise limit** \(\sigma\to0\).  Whether that limit reproduces the deterministic SRB (or another) measure, however, depends on the dynamical system.  Below is a concise roadmap.

---

## 1 The noisy regularisation

Add isotropic white noise:
\[
dX_t=f(X_t)\,dt+\sigma\,dW_t,\qquad \sigma>0 ,
\]
so the stationary density solves
\[
0=-\nabla\!\cdot(f\rho_\sigma)+\tfrac{\sigma^{2}}2\Delta\rho_\sigma .
\]
Because \(\sigma>0\) the density is \(C^{\infty}\) and strictly positive on any connected component that the diffusion can reach.

---

## 2 Zero-noise limit and **stochastic stability**

Let \(\mathcal M_\sigma\) be the invariant measure with density \(\rho_\sigma\) and \(\mathcal M_0\) any deterministic invariant measure supported on the attractor \(A\).

We say the attractor is *stochastically stable* if
\[
\mathcal M_\sigma \;\xrightarrow[\sigma\to0]{}\; \mathcal M_0
\quad\text{(weak convergence).}
\]

### 2.1 Uniformly hyperbolic (Axiom A) attractors  
Stochastically stable.  For flows or diffeomorphisms satisfying Axiom A,
\[
\mathcal M_\sigma \Longrightarrow \mu_{\mathrm{SRB}}
\quad\text{and}\quad
\rho_\sigma\rightharpoonup\mu_{\mathrm{SRB}}
\]
(Kifer 1992; Cowieson & Young 2005).  
Hence you may compute any observable \(g\) as  
\[
\int g(x)\,\rho_\sigma(x)\,dx\;\xrightarrow{\sigma\to0}\;
\int g(x)\,d\mu_{\mathrm{SRB}}(x).
\]

### 2.2 Multiple attractors or non-hyperbolic sets  
The limit can be a **mixture**:
\[
\mathcal M_\sigma\to\sum_k w_k\,\mu_k,
\]
with weights \(w_k\) determined by relative Freidlin–Wentzell escape rates.  
In non-hyperbolic or intermittency-dominated systems the limit may fail to exist or depend on the noise profile.

### 2.3 Gradient systems  
If \(f=-\nabla V\) the stationary density is Gibbs:  
\(\rho_\sigma\propto e^{-2V/\sigma^{2}}\).  
As \(\sigma\to0\) it concentrates into Dirac masses at the minima of \(V\), again yielding mixtures when there are several minima.

---

## 3 Lyapunov exponents via the noisy density

For each \(\sigma>0\) define the *noisy* exponent  
\[
\lambda_i(\sigma)=\int_A\kappa_i(x)\,\rho_\sigma(x)\,dx,
\qquad
\kappa_i(x)=w_i(x)^{\!\top}Df(x)\,v_i(x).
\]

* If the deterministic attractor is stochastically stable and **ergodic**, then
  \[
  \lambda_i(\sigma)\;\xrightarrow{\sigma\to0}\;\lambda_i(0)
  \]
  where \(\lambda_i(0)\) is the usual Lyapunov exponent.
* Smooth dependence \(\lambda_i(\sigma)=\lambda_i(0)+O(\sigma^{2})\) holds for uniformly hyperbolic flows (Ruelle 1982).

Thus the small-noise route gives a rigorous way to replace singular integrals by ordinary Lebesgue integrals, compute, and finally let \(\sigma\to0\).

---

## 4 When is the strategy useful?

| Setting | Zero-noise limit | Practical note |
|---------|-----------------|----------------|
| Axiom A, single attractor | SRB measure | Clean convergence; widely used in numerics and theory. |
| Several attractors | Mixture weighted by escape probabilities | Need Freidlin–Wentzell analysis to get the weights \(w_k\). |
| Non-hyperbolic chaos (e.g. Hénon near tangencies) | May depend on noise details | Regularisation helps numerically but does **not** guarantee a unique deterministic limit. |

---

## 5 Take-away

*Adding a tiny diffusion is a legitimate and often powerful way to “regularise” integrals over a strange attractor.*  
When the attractor is stochastically stable (hyperbolic cases) the procedure recovers the SRB measure and all its ensemble averages—including Lyapunov exponents—without ever invoking singular measures in intermediate calculations.  In non-hyperbolic or multi-attractor situations one must still confront possible mixtures or non-uniqueness in the \(\sigma\to0\) limit, but the method remains the standard bridge between absolutely continuous Fokker–Planck analysis and deterministic invariant measures.

thoughts.content: The user is asking whether adding isotropic Gaussian noise to a deterministic ODE always smooths out the measure. In general, adding non-degenerate noise can lead to a smooth density, but this requires certain conditions: the noise must cover the space and be non-degenerate in directions the vector field can reach. Also, the process needs to be elliptic or hypoelliptic, and the boundary properties must be considered to guarantee absolute continuity and smoothing.

I'm thinking about diffusion matrices: if the matrix is full rank, the density is smooth. Adding isotropic Gaussian noise usually ensures non-degeneracy since it affects all coordinates equally, leading to a full rank diffusion matrix. This typically gives a density with respect to Lebesgue measure. However, guaranteed existence of an invariant measure depends on the system. For example, systems with constant drift outward can lack a stationary distribution. Also, boundary effects can impact smoothing and create singularities in constrained domains.

parts:
### Short answer  
Adding *non-degenerate* isotropic Gaussian noise (diffusion matrix \(\sigma^{2}I_d\) with \(\sigma>0\)) **does give a smooth density for every fixed \(t>0\)**, and any stationary measure that exists is absolutely continuous and \(C^{\infty}\).  
What it does **not** guarantee is that a stationary density exists at all, nor that the small-noise stationary density converges to the deterministic SRB measure in complicated (non-hyperbolic or multi-attractor) systems.

---

## 1 What “smoothing” really means  

* **Transition kernel:** For every \(t>0\) and initial point \(x\) the law of \(X_t\) has a \(C^{\infty}\) density \(p_t(x,\cdot)\) w.r.t. Lebesgue measure.  
* **Stationary measure:** If the SDE admits an invariant probability measure \(\mu_\sigma\), then \(d\mu_\sigma(x)=\rho_\sigma(x)\,dx\) with \(\rho_\sigma\in C^{\infty}\).

Uniform ellipticity of the generator
\[
\mathcal L_\sigma = f\cdot\nabla + \tfrac{\sigma^{2}}2\Delta
\]
provides both properties via classical parabolic PDE theory (or Hörmander’s theorem).

---

## 2 When the stationary density exists  

Adding noise cannot by itself stop trajectories from drifting off to infinity.  
A **Lyapunov (confinement) condition** such as  
\[
\mathcal L_\sigma V(x)\le -cV(x)+C
\quad(c>0)
\]
is required to ensure tightness and yield a unique invariant density.  
Typical cases:

| Drift \(f\) | Noise | Stationary \(\rho_\sigma\) exists? |
|-------------|-------|------------------------------------|
| Dissipative ODE (e.g.\ Lorenz, Van der Pol) | \(\sigma I_d\) | **Yes** – Lyapunov function comes from existing attractor. |
| Linear unstable drift \(f(x)=Bx,\; \text{spec}(B)>0\) | \(\sigma I_d\) | **No** – process explodes, no invariant measure. |
| Hamiltonian flow | \(\sigma I_d\) | **Yes** on compact energy shell, but density is w.r.t. surface measure, not ambient Lebesgue. |

---

## 3 What can still go wrong

1. **Degenerate or anisotropic noise**  
   Rank-deficient diffusion (\(\sigma\) acts only on some coordinates) destroys uniform ellipticity; smooth densities may fail unless Hörmander’s bracket condition closes the missing directions.

2. **Constraints or manifolds**  
   If the state space is a lower-dimensional manifold \(M\subset\mathbb R^{d}\), “isotropic in \(\mathbb R^{d}\)” is no longer non-degenerate on \(M\); smoothing is with respect to the intrinsic volume measure of \(M\), not the ambient \(dx\).

3. **Zero-noise limit may not pick out the SRB measure**  
   Even when \(\rho_\sigma\) exists and is smooth for every \(\sigma>0\), the limit \(\sigma\to0\) can converge to a *mixture* of deterministic invariant measures or depend on how the noise is switched off (Freidlin–Wentzell theory).

---

## 4 Take-away

*For an ODE in \(\mathbb R^{d}\), adding a full-rank isotropic Brownian term \(\sigma dW_t\) is enough to ensure “no singularities” **provided** the resulting diffusion is positive recurrent.*  
That makes Fokker–Planck analysis safe and gives you a \(C^{\infty}\) stationary density \(\rho_\sigma\).  
Just remember that (i) you must still verify recurrence, and (ii) the \(\sigma\to0\) limit needs separate dynamical-systems arguments to recover the deterministic invariant measure you care about.
are the requirements on \rho as t -> infinity to allow \rho_{\sigma} \in C^{\infty} more less strict than requirements for ergodicity?

thoughts.content: This question touches on the relationship between the smoothness of the stationary density \( \rho_\sigma \) and ergodicity. To clarify: the uniform ellipticity of the generator helps ensure smoothness of transition densities (if the stationary density exists). However, ergodicity is stricter because it requires strong mixing properties, like aperiodicity. While smoothness might just need positive recurrence and confinement conditions, ergodicity demands the process be irreducible and meet additional criteria to ensure that the system reaches a unique stationary distribution.

Smoothness of a stationary density requires uniform ellipticity and existence, but does not need the uniqueness required by ergodicity. Ergodicity imposes stricter conditions, like irreducibility and Harris recurrence, ensuring a unique invariant measure. In some systems, there can be smooth stationary densities without ergodicity (e.g., multiple invariant measures). Smoothness typically hinges on nondegenerate diffusion, while ergodicity needs recurrence and some mixing properties. These conditions are closely related, but subtle differences remain, such as the stronger conditions for ergodicity.

parts:
### Two logically separate questions  

| Property you want | What it really concerns | Typical sufficient conditions |
|-------------------|-------------------------|------------------------------|
| **Smooth stationary density** \( \rho_\sigma\in C^\infty \) | *Regularity* of the Fokker–Planck operator acting on functions (local in state space) | **Uniform ellipticity** (or Hörmander hypo-ellipticity) of the generator; plus a Lyapunov (confinement) condition to ensure an invariant measure exists |
| **Ergodicity** of the diffusion | *Long–time behaviour* of the Markov process (global in state space) | Positive recurrence **and** irreducibility (or topological irreducibility + strong Feller) so that the invariant measure is *unique* and attracts all initial laws |

Because the first column is a **regularity** statement and the second a **uniqueness / mixing** statement, the requirements for smoothness are strictly weaker.

---

### 1 Why smoothness comes “for free” once a density exists  

For the SDE  
\[
dX_t = f(X_t)\,dt + \sigma\,dW_t , \qquad \sigma>0 ,
\]
the generator is  
\[
\mathcal L_\sigma = f\!\cdot\!\nabla + \tfrac{\sigma^{2}}2\Delta .
\]

* **Uniform ellipticity** (\(\sigma^{2}I_d\) is positive definite everywhere) → \(\mathcal L_\sigma\) is hypo-elliptic; solutions of \( \partial_t\rho = \mathcal L_\sigma^\* \rho \) are \(C^\infty\) for any \(t>0\).
* If in addition you have a confinement Lyapunov function \(V(x)\) with  
  \[
  \mathcal L_\sigma V \le -cV + C ,
  \]
  (Meyn–Tweedie condition) tightness of transition probabilities follows ⇒ at least one invariant density exists.
* That invariant density inherits the interior \(C^\infty\) regularity from the PDE; boundary regularity is controlled by \(V\).

No irreducibility, aperiodicity, or mixing rate assumptions are needed.

---

### 2 What ergodicity adds on top

An SDE with smooth invariant densities can fail to be ergodic whenever the state space splits into disjoint communicating classes.

* **Disconnected domain example:**  
  Let the drift be dissipative inside two disjoint open balls \(B_1,B_2\) and explode outside; keep the same isotropic noise.  
  Each component has its own smooth invariant density \(\rho_{\sigma}^{(1)},\rho_{\sigma}^{(2)}\).  
  Starting in \(B_1\) you never reach \(B_2\) ⇒ the process is not irreducible ⇒ *not ergodic*.
* **Ergodicity** demands that every two points communicate under the Markov semigroup with positive probability (irreducibility) and that the chain is positive Harris recurrent; these are genuinely stronger, global conditions.

---

### 3 Hierarchy of implications  

\[
\begin{array}{ccccc}
\text{Uniform ellipticity} &+& \text{Lyapunov confinement} &\Longrightarrow& \exists\;\rho_\sigma\in C^\infty \\[4pt]
&&&\text{add irreducibility}&\\[-1pt]
&&&\rotatebox{90}{$\Longrightarrow$}& \text{unique }\rho_\sigma \\[4pt]
&&&\text{add Harris recurrence}&\\[-1pt]
&&&\rotatebox{90}{$\Longrightarrow$}& \text{ergodicity (mixing)}\\
\end{array}
\]

Thus: **smoothness of the stationary density is a prerequisite, but not a guarantee, for ergodicity; its own requirements are strictly lighter.**

---

### 4 Practical takeaway  

If your goal is merely to replace a singular SRB measure by a smooth \(\rho_\sigma\) and then send \(\sigma\to0\), uniform ellipticity + confinement suffices.  
If you also need time-average = space-average statements for *every* initial point (ergodicity), you must additionally verify the usual irreducibility/Harris conditions.

is it correct to say then, that the expectation over the attractor of the log singular values is a more fundamental quantity than lyapunov exponents, which are merely the equivalent value under eergodicity?

thoughts.content: This question is asking about the relationship between expectations over the attractor of log singular values and their connection to Lyapunov exponents. Lyapunov exponents are defined through a time average, while expectations over the attractor can depend on the chosen measure, especially when there's no ergodicity. Without ergodicity, there can be multiple invariant measures, making the expectation over the attractor not uniquely defined. So is expectation more fundamental? I need to carefully explore the difference between local observables and integrals over measures here.

Lyapunov exponents don't require ergodicity, as they are defined for almost every point with respect to any invariant measure. The expectation over the attractor is an integral of the local quantity, with Lyapunov exponents corresponding to the chosen measure. Time averages connect to measure averages under ergodicity, but if not ergodic, exponents maintain constancy along orbits. The expectation depends on the choice of measure, while Lyapunov exponents are more fundamental. This connection ties back to Oseledec's theorem concerning invariant measures and local growth rates.

parts:
Not quite.  
Both objects ultimately come from the **same local observable**

\[
\kappa_i(x)=\bigl(w_i(x)\bigr)^{\!\top}Df(x)\,v_i(x)
             =\left.\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\log\sigma_i(t,x)\right|_{t=0},
\]

but they answer different questions and sit at different logical levels.

---

### 1 Pointwise Lyapunov exponents (Oseledec)  

For **every** initial point that satisfies the integrability condition  
\(\displaystyle\int\!\log^+\!\|Df\|\,d\mu<\infty\),
the limit

\[
\lambda_i(x)=\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\log\sigma_i\bigl(t,x\bigr)
\]

exists.  No measure theory is needed to define it; the statement is purely
trajectory-based.  
If an invariant probability measure \(\mu\) is given, \(\lambda_i(x)\) is constant on each ergodic component but may vary between different components.

---

### 2 Ensemble average of the instantaneous rate  

Given a **specific** invariant measure \(\mu\), one may form

\[
\bar\lambda_i[\mu]\;:=\;\int \kappa_i(x)\,d\mu(x),
\]

which is just the mean value of the local expansion rate under that measure.
By Birkhoff’s theorem, for \(\mu\)-a.e. point

\[
\lambda_i(x)=\bar\lambda_i[\mu]\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
\mu\text{ is ergodic}.
\]

If \(\mu\) is *not* ergodic, \(\bar\lambda_i[\mu]\) is a mixture of the
exponents of its ergodic components; an individual trajectory sees only one of those values.

---

### 3 Which is “more fundamental”?  

| Feature | Lyapunov exponent \(\lambda_i(x)\) | Ensemble average \(\bar\lambda_i[\mu]\) |
|---------|------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------|
| Defined **without** choosing a measure | ✔ | ✖ (need \(\mu\)) |
| Exists pointwise along each orbit (Oseledec) | ✔ | — |
| Changes if you change the initial point but stay in the same ergodic component | ✖ (constant) | ✖ (constant) |
| Changes if you mix two ergodic components | ✖ | ✔ (takes the mixture) |

So the **pointwise exponent** is the primary dynamical invariant; the
ensemble average is a *statistical expectation* of that invariant **after**
one has supplied a particular probability distribution on the attractor.
Under ergodicity they coincide, but the equality is a consequence of Birkhoff,
not a definition of the exponent.

---

### 4 Analogy

Think of kinetic theory:

* **Instantaneous particle velocity** \(v(t)\) – trajectory quantity.  
* **Temperature** \(T=\frac{m}{3k_B}\,\langle v^2\rangle_{\text{ensemble}}\) – an average that coincides with the long-time average only in equilibrium (ergodicity).  
Calling \(T\) “more fundamental” than \(v(t)\) would reverse the logical order.

---

### 5 Take-away

The ensemble expectation  
\(\displaystyle \int\log\sigma_i\,d\mu\)  
is extremely useful—especially when you regularise the measure with small
noise and compute analytically—but it is **derived from**, not prior to, the
Lyapunov exponent.  Ergodicity is the bridge that turns the time-based
definition into a space-based one; it does not demote the exponent to a
secondary role.
wait but you don't need to choose a measure for the ensemble average.. you need only to know that the attractor exists, which is a less strict constraint than ergodicity

thoughts.content: The user mentioned that you don't need to choose a measure for the ensemble average if you know an attractor exists. While it's true that presence of an attractor relaxes some constraints, generally, we still require an invariant measure for proper integration in ensemble averaging. Attractor existence alone doesn't specify which measure to use. So, even though ergodicity provides a uniqueness constraint, without selecting a measure, expectation can't be properly defined.

thoughts.summary: Clarifying ensemble average based on attractor existence
thoughts.content: Expectation in ensemble average always relies on choosing a measure; attractor existence alone doesn’t determine which measure. There could be multiple invariant measures on the same attractor and without a specified measure, defining

parts:
An **expectation is always taken with respect to a measure**; writing a bracket  
\[
\langle g\rangle=\int_{A} g(x)\;d\mu(x)
\]
is meaningless until \(\mu\) is specified.  
Knowing only that a global attractor \(A\subset\mathbb R^{d}\) exists tells you **where** trajectories end up topologically, but says nothing about **how often** they visit different parts of \(A\).  The “how often’’ is precisely the job of an invariant probability measure.

---

### 1 Why an invariant measure does not come for free

* **Topological attractor:** a compact set that attracts every point of some neighborhood.
* **Invariant probability measure:** a Borel measure \(\mu\) with \(\mu(A)=1\) and \(\mu(\Phi^{t}B)=\mu(B)\) for all measurable \(B\) and \(t\).

Krylov–Bogolyubov guarantees at least one invariant measure **when the flow is continuous and the attracting set is compact**, but it may yield:

* many mutually singular invariant measures (e.g. a union of two disjoint periodic orbits each carrying its own Dirac measure);
* mixtures of these measures obtained as limits of time-averaged empirical measures.

Without choosing among them the expectation of \(\log\sigma_i\) is ambiguous.

---

### 2 Ergodicity’s role

Let \(\mu\) be **one** invariant measure.

* If \(\mu\) is **ergodic**, Birkhoff gives  
  \[
  \lim_{T\to\infty}\frac1T\int_0^{T}g(\Phi^{t}x)\,dt
     =\int_{A}g\,d\mu
  \quad\text{for }\mu\text{-a.e. }x .
  \]
  The time average of every typical trajectory equals the ensemble average with respect to the *same* \(\mu\).

* If \(\mu\) is **not** ergodic (a convex combination of ergodic pieces), the time average taken along one trajectory still converges, but only to the component corresponding to the starting point.  
  The single integral \(\int g\,d\mu\) then represents a *mixture* that no individual trajectory realises.

Thus ergodicity is not needed to *define* either Lyapunov exponents or ensemble averages, but it is what lets you equate the two.

---

### 3 Which quantity is “more fundamental”?

| Quantity | Depends on a measure? | Defined for every trajectory? |
|----------|-----------------------|------------------------------|
| **Pointwise Lyapunov exponent** \(\displaystyle\lambda_i(x)=\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\log\sigma_i(t,x)\) | No | Yes |
| **Ensemble average** \(\displaystyle\bar\lambda_i[\mu]=\int_{A}\log\sigma_i(t_0,x)\,d\mu(x)\) (or \(\int\kappa_i\,d\mu\)) | **Yes** – must pick \(\mu\) | No (needs \(\mu\)) |

Because a measure choice is indispensable for any expectation, \(\bar\lambda_i[\mu]\) cannot be called “more fundamental’’ than \(\lambda_i(x)\).  What *is* weaker than ergodicity is the assumption **“there exists at least one invariant measure’’**; but once several such measures exist, the ensemble average is **under-determined** until one is selected.

---

### 4 Practical hierarchy of assumptions

1. **Attractor exists** ⟹ at least one invariant measure exists (compactness + Krylov–Bogolyubov).  
   *You may now define ensemble averages, but you must choose which invariant measure you mean.*

2. **Ergodicity of the chosen measure** ⟹ time averages of typical trajectories equal that ensemble average.  
   *Now Lyapunov exponents computed along almost any orbit equal the integral.*

So:

*Pointwise Lyapunov exponents are primary dynamical invariants.  
Ensemble averages of \(\log\sigma_i\) are secondary statistics that require an explicit invariant measure and coincide with the pointwise values only under ergodicity.*
but lyapunov exponents don't exist without an attractor right? they will not converge unless you have specific assumptions made

thoughts.content: Lyapunov exponents can exist without an attractor, as they are defined for almost every point with respect to an invariant measure according to Oseledec's theorem. They require specific conditions, such as the integrability of the logarithm of the norm of the derivative, but not the presence of an attractor. Without an invariant measure, convergence is not guaranteed, and while finite-time exponents can be defined, a limit cannot always be assured. Attractors help with ergodicity and invariance, but they are not strictly necessary for Lyapunov exponents to exist.

parts:
Not quite.  What Lyapunov exponents **do** require is an **invariant probability measure that satisfies an integrability bound**, not the existence of an attractor in the topological sense.

---

## 1 Oseledec’s theorem—minimal hypotheses

For a \(C^{1}\) flow \(\Phi^{t}\) (or diffeomorphism \(F\)) on a measurable phase space \(X\) with an invariant probability measure \(\mu\):

1. **Integrability condition**

   \[
   \int_{X} \log^{+}\!\bigl\|D\Phi^{\pm1}(x)\bigr\| \; d\mu(x)\;<\;\infty .
   \]

2. **Nothing else.**  
   No compactness, no attractor, no dissipativity, no ergodicity are assumed.

Then for \(\mu\)-a.e. initial point \(x\) the limit

\[
\lambda_i(x)=\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac{1}{t}\log\sigma_i\!\bigl(D\Phi^{t}(x)\bigr)
\]

exists and yields the Lyapunov spectrum at \(x\).

---

## 2 Why an attractor helps but is not essential

* A **compact global attractor** often implies bounded or subexponential growth of the Jacobian, so the integrability bound is automatic for any invariant measure supported there.  
* But one can have exponents without any attractor:

  *Linear example* \(\dot x = Ax\) with \(A=\operatorname{diag}(1,-1)\).  
  Solutions diverge on the unstable axis and collapse on the stable axis; there is **no attracting set**.  
  Taking the (improper) Lebesgue measure restricted to any bounded region fails the integrability test, but the **Dirac measure at the origin** *is* invariant and satisfies it, so Oseledec gives \(\lambda_{1}=1,\ \lambda_{2}=-1\).

* Conversely, a compact attractor does **not** guarantee exponents exist for every trajectory if you insist on using a non-integrable measure (e.g. Lebesgue on a neighborhood if the Jacobian blows up near the boundary).

---

## 3 What fails without the integrability bound

If
\[
\int \log^{+}\!\|D\Phi^{t}(x)\|\,d\mu=\infty ,
\]
Oseledec does not apply.  Finite-time exponents  
\(\displaystyle \frac1t\log\sigma_i(D\Phi^{t}(x))\)  
still make sense, but the limit may fail to exist (oscillate or diverge), so no Lyapunov spectrum is defined.

---

## 4 Role of ergodicity

* **Ergodicity not needed for existence**—only for making the numbers independent of the initial point \(x\) (constant \(\mu\)-a.e.).
* Without ergodicity you get a spectrum \(\lambda_i(x)\) that may vary between ergodic components, yet each value still exists thanks to Oseledec.

---

### Take-away

*Lyapunov exponents hinge on an integrable invariant measure, not on the presence of a global attractor.*  
A compact attractor usually supplies such a measure, but you can have exponents without any attractor at all, and you can have an attractor while exponents fail if the chosen measure violates the integrability condition.
but the oseledec theorem literally uses \mu

thoughts.summary: Clarifying Oseledec theorem and measure μ
thoughts.content: The user is emphasizing that Lyapunov exponents, like Oseledec's, require an invariant measure μ. It's true that Oseledec's theorem uses μ, but what's important is that you can choose any invariant measure. The exponents exist μ-almost everywhere, meaning they hold for almost all points with respect to a given measure. Without a measure, we can't guarantee existence. That said, the exponents themselves are defined pointwise along trajectories, independent of the measure's specifics.

parts:
Exactly — Oseledec’s theorem **is** a measure–theoretic result: it says that if you *choose* an invariant probability measure \(\mu\) satisfying the integrability bound  

\[
\int \log^{+}\!\|D\Phi^{\pm1}(x)\|\,d\mu(x) < \infty ,
\]

then for \(\mu\)-almost every initial state the Lyapunov‐exponent limits exist and the usual splitting holds.

What this does **not** mean:

* that the *definition* of a Lyapunov exponent forces you to introduce a measure;
* or that the exponent at a single initial point cannot be discussed without first picking \(\mu\).

---

### Two logically distinct levels  

| Level | What you need | What you get |
|-------|---------------|--------------|
| **Pointwise definition** | a single trajectory \(x(t)=\Phi^{t}x_0\) | You can try to compute \(\displaystyle\lambda_i(x_0)=\lim_{t\to\infty}\tfrac1t\log\sigma_i(D\Phi^{t}(x_0))\). The limit *may* or may not exist; no measure is invoked. |
| **Oseledec theorem** | an invariant **measure** \(\mu\) + integrability | Guarantees the limit exists for \(\mu\)-a.e. \(x_0\) and provides the measurable invariant splitting. |

So the theorem *uses* \(\mu\) to upgrade “may exist” to “exists almost everywhere”.

---

### Why expectations still require a specific \(\mu\)

The ensemble quantity you proposed,

\[
\int_{A}\log\sigma_i(D\Phi^{t_0}(x))\,d\mu(x),
\]

is an **integral**; it is totally undefined until a single invariant measure—Dirac at a fixed point, SRB, mixture of periodic‐orbit measures, etc.—has been chosen.  
This is true even though Oseledec also uses some measure: both constructions depend on \(\mu\); neither is “measure-free.”

---

### Summary

* Oseledec: “Given **any** invariant \(\mu\) that satisfies the mild integrability bound, the Lyapunov limits exist \(\mu\)-a.e.”  
* Your ensemble average: “Given **that same** \(\mu\), take its expectation of the local growth observable.”  
* Without specifying \(\mu\), neither statement can be made globally; with \(\mu\), both are well defined.  

Therefore the ensemble average is not more fundamental—both quantities stand or fall with the invariant measure you decide to use.
I understand, yo've still just moveed the measure to the existence proof instead of the definition.

thoughts.content: The user is highlighting a valid concern regarding the connection between measure and Lyapunov exponents. They're right that without measure, we can't guarantee existence, but the definition itself doesn't require it at first. In certain cases, like simple linear systems or a hyperbolic fixed point, Lyapunov exponents can be defined for a trajectory independently of measure, though the global property (like existence across the space) needs a measure to be guaranteed. The distinction between definition and existence is fundamental here.

parts:
Exactly —the measure shows up in the *existence theorem*, not in the *formal definition*.  
Whether that feels like “moving the goal-post” depends on what you want from a Lyapunov exponent:

| Question | Needs a measure? | Why |
|----------|------------------|-----|
| “What number do I get if I take **this particular trajectory** and form  \(\displaystyle\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac{1}{t}\log\sigma_i(D\Phi^{t}(x_0))\)?” | **No.** | You can try to compute the limit directly; it may converge, diverge, or oscillate, but the definition itself is measure-free. |
| “Can I be sure the limit exists for *almost every* initial point inside some set?” | **Yes.** | You need a notion of “almost every”, i.e. an invariant probability measure, to make a statement that holds generically. Oseledec supplies that assurance under its integrability hypothesis. |

---

### Concrete examples

1. **Limit exists without invoking any measure**

   \[
     \dot x = Ax,\qquad A=\begin{pmatrix}2&0\\0&-1\end{pmatrix}.
   \]

   The Jacobian is \(e^{At}\); the singular values are \(e^{2t},e^{-t}\).  
   For *every* initial condition the limits  
   \(\lambda_1=2,\;\lambda_2=-1\)  
   exist—no measure required.

2. **Limit fails for some points; measure singles out where it works**

   Piecewise-linear map on the circle that flips orientation at a countable set of points can produce orbits whose Jacobian norm alternates \(2,1/2,2,1/2,\dots\); the limit \(\lim\frac1n\log\sigma\) does not exist for those exceptional orbits.  
   Pick an invariant measure that gives those points weight zero, and Oseledec guarantees existence \(\mu\)-a.e., but the definition itself didn’t change.

---

### How to interpret the hierarchy

* **Definition level** – You can always *ask* for the limit along a single orbit.  
  *Sometimes* you get an answer even in pathological systems.

* **Existence theorem level** – To make a *robust statement* (“for almost every initial condition the limit exists and equals …”) you introduce \(\mu\). That’s where the measure is indispensable.

So, yes: the measure is shifted from the *statement of what the exponent is* to the *theorem that says you’ll actually obtain one almost everywhere*.  The definition itself, however, remains independent of any probabilistic structure.

thoughts.summary: Comparing Lyapunov Exponents and Ensemble Averages
thoughts.content: The user wants a rigorous comparison between pointwise Lyapunov exponents and ensemble averages of log singular values, questioning which is more fundamental. I need to provide a balanced argument where both concepts are intertwined, addressing different perspectives on "fundamental." I'll be careful to define each, clarify their assumptions, and explain how they relate to global vs. statistical invariants, touching on topological invariance for exponents and measure dependence for averages. This will help the user understand how each depends on system behavior.

parts:
Below is a structured comparison that tries to pin down what “more fundamental’’ really means in a dynamical–systems setting, then applies those criteria to  

* **pointwise Lyapunov exponents**  
  \[
  \lambda_i(x_0)=\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\log\sigma_i\!\bigl(D\Phi^{t}(x_0)\bigr),
  \tag{1}
  \]
* **ensemble-averaged local‐expansion rates**  
  \[
  \bar\lambda_i[\mu]=\int_{A}\kappa_i(x)\,d\mu(x)
  ,\qquad 
  \kappa_i(x)=\bigl(w_i(x)\bigr)^{\!\top}Df(x)\,v_i(x),
  \tag{2}
  \]
  where \(\mu\) is an invariant probability measure.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1 What “fundamental’’ can legitimately mean
| Criterion | Why it matters |
|-----------|----------------|
| **C-0 definition** (no extra structure) | Uses only the flow \(\Phi^t\); avoids imposing probabilistic choices. |
| **Existence without contingent hypotheses** | Exists for *some* class of systems even when no invariant measure is known a-priori. |
| **Uniqueness / invariance under smooth conjugacy** | Survives coordinate changes that preserve the dynamics. |
| **Generative power** | Other objects can be expressed as (functions of) it, but not conversely. |

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2 Applying the criteria  

| Criterion | Pointwise exponent (1) | Ensemble average (2) |
|-----------|------------------------|----------------------|
| **C-0 definition** | Needs only the trajectory and the derivative of the flow. | Needs, in addition, an invariant measure \(\mu\). |
| **Existence** | *May* exist or fail for a given orbit; the Multiplicative-Ergodic Theorem (MET) guarantees existence **after** a measure is supplied, but the *definition* itself does not invoke it. | Has no meaning until a measure is specified. |
| **Uniqueness / invariance** | Invariant under \(C^{1}\) conjugacies (Oseledec subspaces transform covariantly). | Changes as soon as one changes \(\mu\) (e.g. switch from SRB to a Dirac on a periodic orbit). |
| **Generative power** | Given \(\lambda_i(x)\) for \(\mu\)-a.e. \(x\), the ensemble average is obtained by integrating. | The reverse is impossible: \(\bar\lambda_i[\mu]\) collapses all pointwise information to a single number and cannot reconstruct the \(\lambda_i(x)\) distribution. |

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3 Concrete examples that separate the two

#### (a) Same ensemble average, different pointwise exponents  
Take a system whose attractor is a union of two disjoint hyperbolic periodic orbits, \(P_1\) and \(P_2\), with exponents \(\{+1,-1\}\) on \(P_1\) and \(\{+2,-2\}\) on \(P_2\).  

Choose  
\[
\mu=\tfrac12(\delta_{P_1}+\delta_{P_2}).
\]
Then  
\(\bar\lambda_1[\mu]=\tfrac12(1+2)=\tfrac32\),  
yet no trajectory ever realises \(+1.5\) as a growth rate.

#### (b) Pointwise exponents exist without an obvious \(\mu\)  
Linear unstable flow \(\dot x=2x,\; \dot y=-y\).  
Every trajectory except \(y\)-axis blows up, but the limits \(\lambda_1=2,\,\lambda_2=-1\) exist for every orbit.  
There is *no* natural finite invariant measure on \(\mathbb R^{2}\) covering all trajectories, so (2) cannot even be stated globally.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4 Why MET does **not** make the measure more fundamental

The Multiplicative-Ergodic Theorem:

* **Input:** a measure \(\mu\) + integrability bound.  
* **Output:** existence and measurability of the exponents \(\lambda_i(x)\) \(\mu\)-almost everywhere.

It uses \(\mu\) **as a technical device** to deliver existence “for many points at once”.  
But once the theorem fires, the resulting \(\lambda_i(x)\) are **geometric numbers attached to individual orbits**, not to \(\mu\).  
If you hand the MET a different ergodic component \(\nu\), you get the *same* \(\lambda_i(x)\) on the orbits that \(\nu\) supports—the measure merely tells you *where* the exponents exist with full probability.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 5 Synthesis

* **Minimal structure:** (1) wins; (2) demands an extra probabilistic layer.  
* **Invariant content:** (1) is retained under conjugacy; (2) can shift by changing \(\mu\).  
* **Information flow:** integrate \((1)\,\Rightarrow\,(2)\); you cannot invert this arrow.

Hence, *by the usual meanings of “fundamental’’ in dynamics—structure-free definition, invariance, and generative power—the pointwise Lyapunov exponents are the primary object. The ensemble average is a secondary statistic obtained after you append a particular invariant measure.*  

That does **not** make ensemble averages unimportant; they are often the quantities we can compute or observe (e.g. via small-noise Fokker–Planck regularisation).  But their construction presupposes the exponents, not vice-versa.
Is there a simple expression for information dimension given \bar\lambda?

thoughts.content: The user is asking about information dimension, potentially referring to the multifractal dimension related to the measure on an attractor. They mentioned ensemble averaged Lyapunov exponents \(\bar\lambda\), which makes me think of theories linking information dimension to Lyapunov exponents and entropy. I’ll want to consider well-known formulas like Kaplan-Yorke, Ruelle, and Ledrappier-Young, which connect these concepts, and figure out how they provide insights into the expression for information dimension given the Lyapunov exponents.

The user's question centers on the relationship between information dimension and Lyapunov exponents. They mention Pesin's formula for entropy and the use of the Ledrappier-Young formula for information dimensions in certain dynamical system contexts. I'll explain that the information dimension can be expressed based on sums of Lyapunov exponents, with formulas specific to SRB measures and systems with certain properties. I'll clarify the association with Kaplan-Yorke for dimension along unstable manifolds, noting the conditions under which simple formulas apply.

parts:
### Information dimension \(D_1(\mu)\)

\[
D_1(\mu)\;=\;\lim_{\varepsilon\to0}\;
        \frac{\displaystyle -\sum_{B\in\mathcal P_\varepsilon}\!
               \mu(B)\,\log\mu(B)}
             {\displaystyle \log\frac1\varepsilon},
\]
where \(\mathcal P_\varepsilon\) is any partition into boxes of diameter \(\varepsilon\).

---

## 1 General hyperbolic measures (Ledrappier–Young)

For a \(C^{1+\alpha}\) diffeomorphism \(F\) with an **ergodic** invariant measure \(\mu\) whose Lyapunov exponents satisfy
\[
\lambda_1\ge\dots\ge\lambda_{d_u}>0>\lambda_{d_u+1}\ge\dots\ge\lambda_d,
\]
write the partial sums
\(S_j=\sum_{i=1}^{j}\lambda_i\) and the *conditional entropies*
\(h_\mu^{(j)}\) defined along the nested unstable flags
\(E^u_j\subset E^u_{j+1}\).

Ledrappier & Young (1985) proved

\[
\boxed{%
D_1(\mu)=
\sum_{j=1}^{d_u-1}\frac{h_\mu^{(j)}-h_\mu^{(j-1)}}{\lambda_{j+1}}
\;+\;
d_u,
\qquad h_\mu^{(0)}:=0 }\tag{LY}
\]

*The \(h_\mu^{(j)}\) are **not** determined by the averaged exponents
\(\bar\lambda_i\).*
Unless you know those conditional entropies, \(\bar\lambda\) alone is
insufficient to recover \(D_1\).

---

## 2 Cases where \(\bar\lambda\) **does** determine \(D_1\)

### 2.1 SRB or “full–entropy” measures  
If \(F\) is \(C^{2}\) and \(\mu\) is an **SRB measure** (or, more generally,
maximises entropy along every unstable subspace) then
\[
h_\mu^{(j)}-h_\mu^{(j-1)}=\lambda_{j}
\quad(j\le d_u).
\]
Plugging this into (LY) collapses the formula to the familiar
**Kaplan–Yorke dimension**

\[
\boxed{%
D_1(\mu)=k+\frac{S_k}{|\lambda_{k+1}|}},
\]
where \(k\) is the largest index with \(S_k\ge0\).
Here \(D_1\) depends **only** on the ensemble-averaged exponents
\(\bar\lambda_i\).

### 2.2 One-dimensional unstable direction  
If \(d_u=1\) then \(h_\mu^{(1)}=\lambda_1\) by Pesin’s formula, so
\[
D_1(\mu)=\frac{\lambda_1}{|\lambda_2|}+1,
\]
again determined solely by \(\bar\lambda\).

### 2.3 Conformal expansion on each unstable subspace  
When \(F\) is conformal (same expansion rate in every direction inside each
\(E^u_j\)) the conditional entropies saturate their upper bounds, reducing
(LY) to Kaplan–Yorke.

---

## 3 When you **cannot** avoid the entropies

* **Non-conformal hyperbolic attractors** in \(d\ge3\).  
  The stretch rates differ inside the same \(E^u_j\), so the
  conditional entropies satisfy
  \(0< h_\mu^{(j)}-h_\mu^{(j-1)} < \lambda_j\).
  Two measures with the *same* averaged Lyapunov spectrum can have different
  information dimensions.

* **Measures that are mixtures of ergodic components.**  
  \(\bar\lambda\) is a mixture of the component spectra; \(D_1\) depends
  on how the mixture weights distribute mass across components of different
  dimensions and entropies.

---

## 4 Bottom line  

*There is a “simple” formula \(D_1=D_{\text{KY}}(\bar\lambda)\) **only** when the invariant measure puts **maximal entropy on every unstable subspace** – that is, in the SRB, conformal, or 1-dimensional-unstable cases.*

In all other situations you must supply additional information
(the Ledrappier–Young conditional entropies) beyond the averaged Lyapunov
exponents to compute the information dimension.

thoughts.content: The user is asking about the relationship between Lyapunov exponents, the Kaplan-Yorke formula, and its connection to information dimension. Yes, when you plug Lyapunov exponents into the Kaplan-Yorke formula, you get an upper bound on the information dimension, not the exact value. The Kaplan–Yorke formula gives the dimension for SRB measures, and in general, it's an upper bound for the information dimension, as well as the box-counting dimension. For ergodic measures on compact manifolds, this bound holds with equality under certain conditions.

parts:
### Kaplan–Yorke (Lyapunov) dimension versus information dimension  

Let the ordered, **space- or ensemble-averaged** Lyapunov exponents be  

\[
\bar\lambda_1\ge\bar\lambda_2\ge\dots\ge\bar\lambda_d ,
\qquad
S_k=\sum_{i=1}^{k}\bar\lambda_i .
\]

Define the *Kaplan–Yorke (KY) dimension*  

\[
D_{\text{KY}}(\bar\lambda)=
k+\frac{S_k}{|\bar\lambda_{k+1}|},
\qquad
k=\max\{j\;:\;S_j\ge 0\}.
\tag{1}
\]

---

## 1 The Ledrappier–Young bound

For any **ergodic** invariant measure \(\mu\) of a \(C^{1+\alpha}\) diffeomorphism (or flow reduced to a Poincaré map) the information dimension satisfies  

\[
\boxed{\;
D_{1}(\mu)\;\le\;D_{\text{KY}}(\bar\lambda)
\;}
\tag{2}
\]

**Why?** The Ledrappier–Young formula  
\[
D_{1}(\mu)=
\sum_{j=1}^{d_u-1}\frac{h_\mu^{(j)}-h_\mu^{(j-1)}}{\bar\lambda_{j+1}}
\;+\;d_u ,
\]
uses the conditional entropies \(h_\mu^{(j)}\) along nested unstable flags.
Each increment satisfies  
\(0\le h_\mu^{(j)}-h_\mu^{(j-1)}\le \bar\lambda_{j}\).
Replacing those entropies by their upper bounds \(\bar\lambda_{j}\) turns the
right–hand side into the Kaplan–Yorke expression (1), giving (2).

---

## 2 When does equality hold?

* **Exact-entropy (SRB) measures on hyperbolic attractors**  
  Conditional entropies saturate the upper bounds:
  \(h_\mu^{(j)}-h_\mu^{(j-1)}=\bar\lambda_j\).  
  Then (2) becomes an equality, so \(D_{1}=D_{\text{KY}}\).

* **One-dimensional unstable bundle**  
  \(d_u=1\) forces equality by Pesin’s entropy formula.

* **Conformal expansion on each unstable bundle**  
  Same expansion rate in every unstable direction ⇒ entropies saturate.

In **non-conformal hyperbolic systems with \(d_u\ge 2\)** or in measures that do not maximise entropy on every unstable subspace, some
\(h_\mu^{(j)}-h_\mu^{(j-1)}\) are strictly smaller than \(\bar\lambda_j\);
then \(D_{1}(\mu) < D_{\text{KY}}\).

---

## 3 What does the upper bound mean in practice?

*Computationally*: you can always take the averaged Lyapunov spectrum, plug it into (1), and get **a rigorous upper bound** on the information
dimension of the invariant measure or the attractor’s support.

*Interpretively*: equality with \(D_{\text{KY}}\) signals that the dynamics spreads mass as uniformly as the expansion rates allow (maximal conditional entropy).  A gap \(D_{\text{KY}}-D_{1}>0\) quantifies how much the measure under-fills the expanding directions because of anisotropic stretching, folding, or partial synchronisation of unstable fibres.

---

### Take-away

* **Yes**—for any ergodic invariant measure the Kaplan–Yorke formula built from the averaged Lyapunov exponents gives an **upper bound** on the information dimension.  
* It becomes the exact value only under additional “maximal-entropy’’ conditions (SRB, conformal, or \(d_u=1\)); otherwise you need the Ledrappier–Young conditional entropies, not just the exponents, to obtain \(D_{1}\) exactly.
